reviewText: The decade of the 80's produced some classic, great films. But none captures the dreamy fantasyworld of that time better than The Neverending Story. Disregard the other sequels, this is the only good one. It is  magical, wondrous, and enveloping. I am truly in love with this film.  Everyone should experience its magic.

The theme of reconciliation with dad that occurs in the Neverending Story might be great for all those kids out there with great dads, but for my kids whose dad doesn't reconcile/apologize for anything, I think the movie  teaches kids they have to be heroes themselves and maybe then dad will come  and everything will be alright. Do you know how hard kids try to make this  happen? Let this be a cue to dad's out there to watch the movie and, if  there's ever been a time when your relationship with your kid wasn't great,  to go to your kid and apologize and get some professional help for both of  you to really work it out.

When I first saw this movie at 11 years, words could not describe the emotions I felt.  The Neverending Story has been my favorite ever since, even at 25.  It is magical. I still get goosebumps every time I see the  movie.  The soundtrack is wonderful, such beautifull music. You can almost  imagine yourself there with Bastian and Atreju.  I am an adult and proud to  say that this movie inspires me and it always will!  I love to read,  especially fantasy novels.  If you like to leave it all behind and go some  place wonderful just follow Bastian as he reads his story.  Bastian is a  young boy having a hard time dealing with the death of his mother and also  a father who insists he grow up much to fast.  He reads The Neverending  Story, which is about a boy warrior, Atreju.  Atreju is on a quest to find  a way to stop the Nothing, a horrible thing which is eating up Fantasia.  The warrior must travel thousands of miles and meet many enchanting friends  along the way.  As Atreju goes on this quest Bastian discovers that he is  living vicariously through Atreju and that this story, this quest is all  meant to reach him.  Bastian realizes he is a very important part and that  he alone can save Fantasia. He learns that his dreams and imagination are  all part of life and are a necessity. Without our imagination we are all in  a sad existence and easily controlled because we have no drive, no  inspiration.  Watch it, keep and open mind and heart and you will see that  you are also a part of The Neverending Story.

My 7 year old son loved this movie.  He especially loved the special effects (even thought they are over 30 yrs old!).  Big laughs at the end when Bastian chases the bullies and they run away like maniacs.  Still a classic.  Enjoy.

One of my ALL time favorite movies! There's a bit of the Irish mythologies in it, which is a plus. I wonder is this move one of Jim Henson's great movies of the 1980s? (Jim Henson Company of Muppets fame)? You can't expect to see computer generated effects when no one but NASA even had computers back then, and they used punch cards to run programs in batches. But that doesn't matter, because the story itself holds up so well. A fantastic, well done story always trumps effects anyway, and it's great to see a movie where story is the most important and does not suffer because of effects. It's a generous, moving film.

Only buy this movie if you REALLY loved it in 1984. A friend told me it was a great story. I barely managed to watch the horrible, fake, scenes and special affects of the 1980s. The kid screaming like a quacker, he needs some therapy. Both kids do. I am not sure the point of the story made any sense. Good grief, there's 2 hours of my life I can't get back!

I'll keep this short and sweet. Seeing this movie at age 9 had a major impact on the course of my life.  I paid extra at the local tax collector's office to have a personalized license plate on my car that is a reference to The Neverending Story. For me, It was that good of a movie. Obviously not everyone will love it as much as I do, but if you enjoy movies such as Willy Wanka, The Goonies, and The Princess Bride than is is right up your alley. To me, the Neverending Story is the pinnacle of live action kid's movies that adults will also enjoy . Watch it with your kids - you will be glad you did!

So I've grown up, and decided to buy this for my own children, as part of an initiative to expand their exposure of live-action animatronic movies from Jim Henson. These days everything is animated with computers, and it's just not the same. Anyways....  my family loved it, and it's become one of my daughter's most favorite movies right now. I had a good bit of nostalgia that was great. Will probably be watching this over and over again, because that is how children are with movies they like. The movie does have some mildly spooky parts, nothing that would IMHO cause nightmares, but your miles may vary depending on the child and age. Finally, the theme music for this movie was great, and the entire musical score was 1980's new-wave synth pop! Actually we started playing the theme music via internet streaming audio because the kids just like it that much..

***Spoiler Alert***

Bastian, a shy and friendless child, is on his way to school when some bullies pick on him. In an attempt to escape their torture, Bastian hides in a bookshop. The owner, Mr. Coreandor, is grumpy. He stumbles upon a book and Mr. Coreander warns him against reading the book. Bastian is intrigued so he grabs the book and leaves a little note promising to return the book. Bastian goes into the school attic and starts reading.

In the book, he discovers a place called Fantasia. He is quickly drawn into their world. He learns of "The Nothing" and the fact that it is slowly killing Fantasia. The Ruler, a child-like Empress, is sick and an Indian boy, Atreyu is tasked with finding the cure. The people of Fantasia believe that once the Empress is cured, "The Nothing" will be demolished. Atreyu is given the Orin as a protection. I cried when his horse, Artax was claimed by the swamp :(

This is a brilliant movie with such originality. I loved the Luckdragon, Falkor, Mora the Turle Mountain,  and all the other characters. To me as a child, it was funny, scary and sometimes nail-biting. Bastian plays such a big role in the book as well.

I highly recommend that every kid watch this movie because it has so much to teach us. Plus the soundtrack is ...

This book-to-movie is one of the worst ever--the acting is terrible, the screenplay is a mishmash of moments from a truly magical meta-book (that is a meditation about the miraculous act of reading as much as it is an imaginative adventure for kids), and the SFX are laughable. But it's a product of its times, you say. Perhaps, perhaps, but the overall quality of movies and TV shows being made for kids today is so astronomically better than it was back in 1984 that my kids (who are as eager for the new and as any consumer fattened in the West during the Age of Information) knew right away that this was just an awful piece of crap. And there were plenty of other kids' movies from that era that respected their audiences and trafficked in similar material: THE PRINCESS BRIDE, for instance, which is as good now as it ever was. I wish that I could go back and unwatch it twice: the first time I saw it, when I was a kid, and the second time, when in a fit of nostalgia (and a spasm of failing memory) I watched it again with my own kids. Avoid at all costs.

Truly my favorite movie when I was a child. As a child that moved around a lot, due to my stepdad being in the military, I related to the story. Being the new kid in school was not easy and being able to escape in a story helped. This is also what imagine when when my 6 years old son reads his books and acts them out. The plot is great and opens the imagination. A true classic. There are so many wonderful characters that were created for the film. I was up on my seat when I first watched when he had to go through the two sphinxes. The rock biter is big lovable characters that grows on you throughout the story. I have watched the movie over 100 times throughout my life, and I must say this is my favorite movie still at age 38. It brings back so much memories of my childhood. I only wish they continued with the story.

The voice-over of the princess can cause nightmares if one listens too closely. The flying, fury luck dragon resembles [MATURE CONTENT] that it becomes absurd. Plus, it's stupid. It's hard to believe this movie is by Wolfgang Peterson. Yes, that Wolfgang Peterson, the one who made "Air Force One" and "In the Line of Fire." Oh yeah, and "Das Boot"! In fact, he went straight from "Das Boot" to "The Neverending Story." But make no mistake: this one is a kids' movie.

I loved it as a kid. I wanted to ride on the back of a Luck Dragon and have that dragon make all of my bully problems jump into dumpsters. I wanted to become a part of the books that I read. I wanted to ride with Atreyu and help him defeat the Gmork and the Nothing. I loved this movie.

And my kids loved it when we just watched it.

But this is a kids' movie.

Adults can still enjoy it, but there are parts that are very, very slow, and some of the acting is laughable. In fact, whenever the Luck Dragon would talk, I couldn't help but laugh at it. It really is a silly kids' movie. And kids don't really care about things like dialogue and acting. As an adult, parts of it didn't really work for me.

Like most film adaptations of fantasy novels, The Neverending Story will please some and not others. As a child of the late 70's and Early 80's, this film is inscribed indelibly on my psyche as a formative work. Fans of Labrynth, Dark Crystal, etc. will love it. I recently showed this to my own kids, and they also loved it.

More than a mere child's movie, it delves into the inner mechanisms of self worth.  There will br trials and tribulations,  but if you believe in yourself,  then ultimately,  you will prevail.

The special effects were top of the line when it came out, but will look very dated to someone that isn't used to 80s genre movies.

A great movie for all ages once you look past some of the graphics and music.

Although we all know that the production value of this film pales in comparison to modern movies, it's still a hit with my kids.  They enjoy it as much as I did, and they have asked for it multiple times.  I have a five year old boy and a six year old girl, and there's a boy hero and a girl empress - plus, the actors are close enough to their ages that it really hits home.  How does it get better?  Yes, there are a couple of hard spots when a character gets taken by the nothing (the horse is particularly hard), but remember - spoiler - that everything works out in the end.  Bonus for kids is that you can pause it so that you can explain that they don't have to worry because they do win in the end and all of the things that went wrong will be put right.  Exciting and nothing tacky or abrasive.  Plus, good triumphs over evil and it gives kids a sense of control that they can make a difference.

I'm only here to comment that you should force plain old stereo when watching this movie, as the 5.1 upscaling that was done by my receiver made it unbearable, which is not the usual experience for me. After my kid insisted we watch it again, the next day, a second time in a row, we watched it on the smaller TV which has no surround sound and it was 10 times more pleasant to watch, no dynamic volume problems.

I found with the surround sound I was constantly turning down the thunderstorm sounds and then turning up the speech. I never have to do that for movies new or old, but this one was particularly bad for that.

This movie has unfortunately lost its magic now 30 years out. The puppets and graphics are painful to watch. The characters are overacted and the protagonist only has two types of speech: talking and yelling. The world is arguably imaginative but the storyline is overly linear and oftentimes wrapped up in vague, confusing explanations. I also question the messages that are delivered namely: dealing with loss and difficulty by getting literally lost in a book while in a school attic without telling anyone where you are. Instead of learning to deal with life's problems the character instead runs away from them and becomes even further removed from society.

This is a sentimental favorite for the age I was when I first watched it.  I'm not going to reveal any plot spoilers except in the abstract. Second, Tami Stronach was the first time I ever realized a girl could be pretty.  It's kind of weird seeing her again as a nearly 40-year-old man and still finding her hot.

The problem for me was with the quality of the presentation on the Amazon download viewed through the FireStick. The image was super dark. In some of the scenes in the woods where the rock monster talks to the snail and that group, you could barely make out the characters on the screen. (Toshiba HD screen with decent black levels). This isn't Amazon's fault as they are just hosting the digital file given to them by the movie studio, but the print really needs to be brightened a bit to bring it back to it's original 1980's big screen glory. Even the VHS I had of this 20 years ago has more color depth.

The movie is still watchable, but it gets a little annoying during the really dark scenes.

AMAZON
This review is an excerpt from my book Killer Bs: The 237 Best Movies On Video Youve (Probably) Never Seen, which is available as an ebook on Amazon. If you enjoy this review, there are 236 more like it in the book (plus a whole lot more). Check it out!

THE NEVERENDING STORY: Eight-year-old Bastian (Oliver) is taking the death of his mother very hard. He spends his days daydreaming, frightened by life and terrorized by bullies. One day they chase him into an antique bookstore, where he discovers and borrows a rare storybook entitled The NeverEnding Story. Hiding in his schools attic, he begins reading, fascinated by the incredible characters that populate the magical land of Fantasia, and by the adventures of young warrior Atreyu (Hathaway), sent on a quest to save Fantasia from The Nothing, a mysterious plague which swallows reality and leaves only emptiness in its wake.

Bastian finds himself irresistibly drawn into Atreyus adventures, their fates mystically intertwined. And when the Empress (Stronach) appeals directly to Bastian from the pages of the enchanted manual, can he find the courage to believewhich is the only way to save Fantasia?

Discussion: Poet T.S. Eliot called it the objective correlative: a metaphor so perfect and powerful that it freights with it an exact emotional experience. For Bastian, the storybook in The NeverEnding Story is the objective correlativeand for the viewer, the movie serves the same purpose, as we are eerilyand properlyincorporated into the action.

The best fairy tales contain mystery, a moral message (here, facing your fears), a touch of darkness, and pure primal emotionsfear, despair, courage, joyand allow us to participate in the catharsis they provide. What a rare film it is that offers all this, if only one is willing to be absorbed in the story! The NeverEnding Story is both modern mythology and a loving tribute to innocence and the infinite power of the imagination. Its a film not just for children, but for the unrepentant dreamer in us all.

I watched this again after well over 20 years. I watched it for the first time with my seven year old. He loved it (but was afraid of the wolf.) Two things stood out: 1) The story is a bit "complicated" (or maybe abstract) for "youngsters"--but it did give us the "open opportunity" to pause and explain imagination and how "it's up to you to create 'things' in this world"), 2) The visual effects and visuals are still stunning. (I've been a visual effects expert in Hollywood for 20+ years.) If it weren't for the mouthes on the creatures not "keeping up with" or perfectly syncing with spoken dialogue (puppetry was used), one would be hard-pressed to believe this movie was not done in the "modern era" of special effects. "Now-a-days" everything and anything is accomplished with computer graphics, but this masterpiece preceded "all of that." It's a testament to the art, craft, and "manual" talent of the makers of this film. Wow. 'like staring at the Golden Gate Bridge or realizing the Apollo missions got to the moon way, way before modern computer technology was even prophesied. From make-up, to costumes, to matte paintings and dye-tank cloud effects, it leaves me in awe, and almost longing for the "good old days" where artists "rolled up their sleeves" and physically made wonderful, beautiful, and awe-filled things! So many scenes are simply breath-taking. (Ignoring a few black [matte] outlines, it's flawless!) Bravo!

I was surprised at this one.  "The Neverending Story" was always touted as a classic in my youth; people talked about it with a touch of reverence, but I never got around to watching it.  I finally took a look, and found that about halfway through I was bored; reading reviews, that is not an uncommon reaction.  Maybe it's one of those films that little kids adore, and if you try to re-watch it later the illusion is shattered.  Kind of like seeing current photos of actresses/actors you crushed on as a kid, and realizing how old and unattractive they've gotten...and realizing you're in the same boat.

2.5 stars. Although it's nice to see a kids' fantasy movie from the age when it was all still done with puppets, sets and costumes instead of gajillion dollars' worth of CGI, this isn't great. Even for a kids' movie the writing is clunky and prosaic, the acting gets pretty awful, and the pace is slow enough to send most any kid to the land of nod, especially in today's whizbang kids' world. I get why folks who saw it as kids back in the day might be nostalgically fond of it, and it has its moments, but generally it's meh. If for some reason you're looking for 80s fantasy films for kids, there are better ones

Atreyu: But why is Fantasia dying, then?
G'mork: Because people have begun to lose their hopes and forget their dreams. So the Nothing grows stronger.
Atreyu: What is the Nothing?
G'mork: It's the emptiness that's left. It's like a despair, destroying this world. And I have been trying to help it.
Atreyu: But why?
G'mork: Because people who have no hopes are easy to control; and whoever has the control... has the power!

As for the content of the movie, I probably would have loved it if I had seen it as a child like I should have, but seeing it as an adult left a lot to be desired. I'm sure it would be good to show to your children if you're busy corrupting them with the other 80s and 90s hits you grew up with! The old 2010 blu-ray of this classic Timeless film was insulting had no special features at all
and the blu-ray transfer was s***
for some fans that don't know this film was 60% German made, German filmed
and about 40% American/British made
the film is based on German author Michael ende book of the same name of the film

there's 2 blu-ray versions, the WB 30th Aniversary edition & the 2012 German blu-ray version
first the 30th Anniversary edition
this time Warner bros have given fans brand new special features
1st Featurette RE-IMAGINING THE NEVERENDING STORY
which is 25min new recollections from the German Production team from the film
Wolfgang peterson, Producer Dieter Geissler, Screenplay writer Herman Weigal
Cinematographer Jost Vacano & Music Composer Klaus Doldinger
plus interviews with American executives Mark Damon & John Hyde.
the German crew speak English for this new featurette, no subtitles
only 2 Actors from the film have been newly interviewed Tami stronach & Gerald McRaney who played Bastian's father
Barret oliver & Noah hathaway who played Atreyu are not interviewed for some reason
maybe they were asked but Declined
this new featurette should've gone for maybe 40mins i think, but still very interesting to watch

2nd new featurette is RESTORATION
which is 10min interview with the person who did the blu-ray restoration for the film
the interview is German with English subtitles obviously, no surprise there
i couldn't see the point watching it, but it's here on the blu-ray

plus a new Audio commentary by Wolfgang peterson, very interesting commentary to
he gives more recollections on the film

there's also 2 Documentaries on this blu-ray
1st Doco is a 20mins featurette
MAKING OF THE NEVERENDING STORY
filmed in 2004 for the 2 Disc dvd German release only
in German language with English subtitles again

the 2nd Doco  A WORLD OF FANTASIES
which has previously been watched on youtube.com as bootleg footage is now officially released on this blu-ray
55mins Behind the scenes on set footage in Germany 1983-1984 of the making of the film
very interesting behind the scenes footage if you can tolerate the English subtitles

there's also the 2012 German blu-ray release by Constantine film
which is the Extended version of The Neverending story run time 101mins
which i bought from amazon.de just to watch for curiosity reasons
this German version has roughly 4-5mins of extra scenes & Dialogue in the film
the extra scenes are not new scenes but are extra Dialogue & footage from the original scenes
in the U.S. version that's all
most noticeably is the end scene with Child empress crying out to Sebastian
this has been extended for an extra minute with footage of the Ivory tower crumbling

so both German & U.S. versions are very similar to each other
you can easily select English language 5.1 surround sound option in setup
so there are no English subtitles
but some of the Characters have been Dubbed in American English thou
for eg Indian Actor Deep roy who played Teeny weeny with his Racing snail has been Dubbed
by a very thick Texan Actor which does sound bizarre
Actor Tilo pruckner who plays Nighthob has been Dubbed aswell
Alan Oppenheimer who did the voice over work for the Gmork in the U.S. version
has a completely different voice, someone else did the Gmork voice in the German version
apart from that Falkor and the other Actors Patricia Hayes & sydney bromley voices are exact the same
Childlike empress & Atreyu voice's have not been Dubbed it's the same voice as the U.S. version.
the blu-ray transfer for the German release is exactly the same as the U.S. blu-ray
nice sharp & clear picture quality in 2:35:1 widescreen
the extras on the German blu-ray are 2004 retrospective German TV broadcast in German language
with English subtitles

the new special features is 30 years in the making & finally on blu-ray
this film has finally been given the respect it Deserves
personally i like both versions so i'm Happy i bought the German blu-ray aswell
i gave this 30th Anniversary & the German blu-ray 5 stars for sure, worth the cash for sure
you can easily buy the German blu-ray of amazon.de and get it shipped to the U.S.

The Neverending Story is an 80s fantasy classic that holds a special place in my heart due to the fact that I grew up loving the movie (as I'm sure is the case for many others). Now that I'm an adult, I have an even greater appreciation for all of the technical wizardry that went into the making of the film, and I've only grown to love it even more. Needless to say, I was really looking forward to this Anniversary Edition because of the announcement that it had been remastered. As such, you can imagine my disappointment when I bought the disc only to find that, in actuality, it contains the same transfer as the 2010 blu-ray which I already sold in anticipation of this new one. To add insult to injury, there's even a featurette about the restoration on the blu-ray - a restoration that clearly wasn't used for this release. How this could have happened is beyond me, but I am an extremely disappointed fan, and I can't help but feel that I was duped into buying this Anniversary Edition due to false advertising.

To be fair, the new special features are extremely welcome, and the movie is wonderful in any shape or form, but seeing as Wolfgang Petersen himself has taken issue with the color timing of the current transfer, the movie is clearly in need of a remaster. Regardless of how the movie looks, the bottom line is we were promised a remaster, and we didn't get one. I'm giving this release two stars for the special features and because the movie itself is great, but that's being generous because WB really dropped the ball on this one. If they give us a proper remastered disc and offer an exchange program, I'll happily edit my review to reflect the fact that they've made amends. Until then, I'll be thinking twice about my future WB purchases.

The problem is use of the previous video transfer however announced as REMASTERED. IT IS NOT =[
Terrible marketing Warner!!

"Each film restored" written in ads and "Restoration" written on back of Blu-ray cover is intentional false advertising.

How could it be a quality control mistake if the ads and cover have such little information to begin with?

This review is based on The Neverending Story 30th Anniversary blu ray.  This is not a review of the movie (the movie earns a 4.5/5 from me).

Neverending Story was previously released on blu ray back in 2010 as a bare bones edition with marginal picture quality, much was left for improvement.

Warner Brothers decided to re-release Neverending Story as a 30th Anniversary edition in 2014 and marketed the film as having a new remaster.  This has ended up being a complete falsity, it's the exact same transfer as the edition put out in 2010 without any upgrade in video or audio quality.  Their promotion department are now back-peddling on all the advertisements they've been putting out since June of 2014.

The only difference between this release and the previous is the addition of a few extra features.  One of the extra features is an in-depth documentary about the remastering process used on the film except this special feature doesn't even apply to this edition!  It's about the European release which did have a remaster done; this only adds salt to the wound for fans of the film hoping for the best quality available in the United States.

Warner Brothers really messed up with this release.  My advice, buy the cheaper version without the few measly extra features and save $7-10, here is the link to that release: http://www.amazon.com/Neverending-Story-Blu-ray-Noah-Hathaway/dp/B002Z7FM68/ref=tmm_blu_title_1?_encoding=UTF8&sr=&qid=

The 1 star isn't for the movie, the movie is fantastic, the 1 star is because this is just a repackage of the first release with NO "Restoration" done to it, even thou WB said this movie was supposed to be Restored/Remastered/etc, now they claim it was a mistake & only the 2nd movie (which is crap), got an overhaul.

If you have the first release, save your money, heck, maybe pick up a copy of the German Extended version, from Amazon.de, it contains the Limahl theme song, as well as a better looking version of this classic movie.
A SCAM by Warner, who had advertised this as a remaster, when in fact, it is just a re-issue of the same old terribly dark transfer from 2010. Shame on you, Warner!
super!!
Kid and wife still love it. Classic movie that is a bit cheesy due to age, but I think this movie will age far better than a lot of the other films coming out far later.

Unfortunately WB's lied to us and just used the old 2010 transfer for this new disk.  Calling it a remaster is false advertising and I sent WB's a complaint and I advise everyone else who purchased this Blu-ray to do the same.

Odd that so many reviewers found this movie inspiring. I can only assume they never read the book. The movie starts out well, but ends with a childish rampage in which the hero--riding on the back of his pet dragon--takes childish revenge against his childhood tormenters. This ending is completely unrelated to the book, which has far more powerful and important points to make.

Upon seeing what was done to his story without his knowledge, Michael Ende the usually reserved and thoughtful author held an impassioned press conference to denounce "that revolting movie" and demanded that his name be removed from the credits. It was.

"The makers of the film simply did not understand the book at all," he complained. "They just wanted to make money."

I highly recommend reading the book first. Better yet, only read the book and skip the movie. which only serves to insult a great author, a beautiful story, and its viewers--while the perpetrators smile to the bank.

This is classic fantasy adventure for kids from around 6-8 up. Be forewarned though, there are some situations and creatures that young children may find scary. It has Henson'esque style creatures and can be frightening in much the same way a movie like "Labyrinth" can be. Other than that, it is just a great story about the power of imagination and why books are still relevant in a more modern age. I loved this as a child, and I still do. One particular scene, that may or may not involve a swamp, was the first movie scene I ever witnessed that made me weep in abject grief. It was a good learning experience though. It toughened me up.

Bastion  (Barrett  Oliver)  loves  reading,  but  could  care  less  about  studying,  &  avoids  a  math  test.  I  wasn't  any  good  with  math  myself  &  I  hated  it.  The  guy  at  the  Book  store,  says  he  doesn't  like  Kids,  but  soon  softens  up  to  Bastion  after  he  tells  the  man  about  him  being  chased  by  bullies.  First  suggestion,  tell  the  school  principal  so  they  can  be  dealt  with.
Anyways  he  must  have  been  exaggerating  when  he  said  no,  You  can't  take  the  book.  That's  how  adults  are,
Bastion  did  take  an  interest  in  the  book.  Its  got  an  Orin  symbol  on  the  cover,  the  kind  of  book  that  makes  your  imagination  come  alive.
The  star  of  the  story  is  about  a  young  boy  named  Atreu  (Noah Hathaway)
who  goes  on  a  quest  to  find  a  cure  for  the  impress,  if  a  cure  for  the  impress  is  found  the  Nothing  will  stop  destroying  the  land.  The  adventures  exciting,
as  him  &  Artex  his  horse  begin  their  journey.  But  an  enemy  werewolf  creature  that  Atreu  wasn't  warned  about  is  out  to  stop  Atreu.  He  must  overcome  tremendous  odds,  seek  advice  or  suggestions.  &  he  &  Falcor  fly  at  zooming  speeds  trying  to  get  ahead  of  the  nothing  before  it  takes  fantasia  out  of  existence.  Bastion  eventually  comes  forth  to  save  fantasia  &  meets  the  child  like  impress  (Tami Stronach).  Makes  his  first  wish  then  takes  his  own  ride  on  Falcor.  I  enjoyed  every  moment  of  the  movie.  No  question  about  it.
I've  seen  part  2.  Its  not  even  half  as  good.  &  if  they  say  part  3  isn't  any  good,  I'll  take  their  word  for  it!

I remember watching this film adaption as a youth. From my childhood I remember vague scenes of a great white dragon,a  scary rock Neanderthal, a beautiful white horse, and a cute but brave Native American boy.

I recently watched this as an adult and finally realized the true theme and meaning of the story.

We find our hero, Bastian, suffering from melancholy after the passing of his mother. His authoritative father tells him to basically man up, which I find a tad bit rude for a 9 year old, but hey, I'm not a parent, so what do I know? Anywho, after witnessing some authentic 80s bullying, Bastian winds up in an old book store where he uses his five finger discount to obtain a book that is not for him by a crazy old dude.

Upon his arrival to school, he decides early on that math is clearly not an important subject (hellooo calculators, T-83s!!!) And why take a quiz when you know where the spare key to the attic of your school is?

Bastian is able to find some extremely flammable candles in the extremely wooden attic with the magical matches they leave around in 80s elementary schools (that's a lawsuit waiting to happen). He becomes encompassed into the world of Fantasia, which is quickly vanishing away by "The Nothing." The young Native American takes on the challenge of a quest to save his world. [SPOIL ALERT]: You see some pre PETA scenes early on with Artex the beautiful white pony. Atreyu (the native) forges through a tough and brutal quest including passing extremely large chested sphinxes, while hearing the dismay and defeated woes of Fantasia's people. Real Debbie downer types.

Eventually, Atreyu meets a creepy animatronic white dragon who admits he enjoys watching Atreyu sleep. Atreyu then rides on the dragon over the same multi-landscape shots, many times (this part was basically an ode to 'Merica!) And, Yeah for green screens!

There's mention of an empress too but really this is mostly a young male viewer movie so she's literally only in the end of it. That's it.

During this entire quest, a large wolf monster decides it must also destroy and kill Atreyu. [ SPOIL ALERT]: Atreyu finally comes vis-a-vis to this wolf creature had a deep philosophical discussion on why people with no hope *cough* depression *cough* are easy to control, and control means power. Dang wolf, that's some real existential stuff there. Nietzsche would be impressed. [SPOIL ALERT]: The confrontation ends with literally no effort at all, where the wolf pretty much just commits suicide. Wow, all that chasing for THAT?!?!

All in all the movie was solid gold for the 80s. If you're not a fan of the plot, then hopefully you can at lest enjoy those awesome synths and totally 80s music!

This was one of my favorite movies when I was younger. It was before the days of CGI graphics yet it has some very impressive special effects.  I remembered the story being a lot better than it was.  I never read the novel but the movie just moves very quickly and hops around, often at the expense of the viewer.  I never really felt like I understood the motivations of the characters.  Even though a fantasy, it seemed juvenile in how characters responded to situations; events in the real world just didn't seem believable.

For the fun and frivolous nature of the movie, I give it high marks.  As for the story and character, I would rate it only a 2 stars -- averaging it out to 3 stars.

The story and the graphics seemed a bit dated.  I am not a fan of New Age philosophy.  In the end all the boy had to do was imagine the bullies being defeated.  We can't continue to live in a world of fantasy, even as a child.

An amazing tale of whimsy and fantastic artistic benevolence enchants even the most hardened movie goer. The childlike empress's words speak directly to your soul, bringing you into the screen, as Atreyu, the gold hearted Indian boy, inspires your wild side to explore and champion your fear. This movie will roll you like rockbiter's enormous rock scooter and fly your fancy to new levels as you desperately grab the soft, scaly fur of Falkor, the luck dragon, for the ride of your life!

The Neverending Story , is a must see movie. Back in `84 when it was released on VHS , it was a must see. I have been hooked ever since. To truly understand what this movie is telling you , watch it more than once. Just watching it once and not truly understanding the underlying story would be an injustice to yourself.

This is not just a kids movie , although kids will love it , they will not understand the true meaning , but thats fine.

As an adult watching this movie and understanding what is really being told , you can come away with a whole new understanding of life.

Yes , it is that kind of movie.

It is a work of fiction , but I ask you , what is real and what is an illusion ?

Watch it have some fun , then watch it again and understand.

You will enjoy.

Gary
This is a classic that every child with an experience should experience. A great movie to watch with the whole family!

We have had family movie night weekly for the last 3 years. As a result,  we are always game (desperate) to try anything. My husband and I remembered The Neverending Story well and we were excited to share it with our kids,  but this is no Princess Bride (CLASSIC!). We expected it to look cheesy, and it does, but we didn't expect the movie to be so lame. The acting sucks and we were never engrossed so I found myself thinking things like, "how could I have EVER found that dog-dragon cool?" instead of caring about Atreyu and their planet. I watch movies and read books to escape but I never forgot all the other things I needed to get done like laundry or cleaning. My husband literally fell asleep (we started the movie at 7:00 pm on s Saturday and he is only 32 years old!). There are numerous write ups about the actual plot, so I don't need to rehash that.  I just wanted to say that the movie is not engaging and other than the last 10 to 15 minutes, it is a complete waste of time. I am going to recommend anyone interested in the story to get the book; it has to be better. Trust me, your memories of this movie are better than the actual movie.

I've watched this movie countless times since I was 3 years old. I'm 33 now and still watch it a few times each year. It's had quite an affect on the development of my consciousness. Love isn't the word; The NeverEnding Story is a part of me. The scene at the end with the Childlike Empress is so powerful (still makes me cry!). She's pleading with us to not give in to The Nothing, and to keep hope alive and to continue to imagine and wish and create!
Yeah I said it. If you or your kids have never seen this then you are doing the world a disservice!

To begin:

The Neverending Story is a masterpiece. Yes, it's filled with flaws. Yes, it's more of a child's movie. Yes, it's a bit corny. But this movie represents sooooo much more. It represents human fantasy and dreams. This is one of the movies I watched as a child that made me love fantasy. I grew up watching this movie and loved it so much and watching it on Blu-ray is amazing.

Quality:

From what I can gather, the back cover of the movie say's "HD" but it actually looks closer to DVD quality. The movie is in a wide screen format, and even on wide screen TV (16:9 ratio) it will still look like a movie screen format. The Blu-ray case and disc are good quality and well worth the money. It shipped on time and was actually faster than I expected. Video quality seems to be DVD SD level, but it COULD have been cleaned up more than it seemed. The "Nothing" moments (swirling clouds of darkness) actually did look to be in HD.

Special Features: None

Nostalgia Factor: High

Over All: Good product. If you liked this movie as a kid, you will still love it when you are older. This movie has a charm that never goes away. Seeing this movie in "HD" is pretty awesome. I highly recommend this movie, though if you can find it on DVD, you might be better off as far as the price goes.

I'm a child of the 80's so this movie is a concentrated dose of pure nostalgia. I used to own the DVD but when I wanted to share it with younger friends who'd never seen it I realized someone had taken it from my collection. So I bought here on Amazon and we devoured it with no problems.

This was one of my favorite movies growing up and it had a lot to do with planting the seeds of my lifelong obsession with the fantasy (and later scifi) genres of fiction.

The characters are classic and the monsters/creatures are old school animatronics/puppets so there's no odd out of place CGI.

It's a great watch for a family or anyone interested in how imagination applied to fantasy movies before the rampant reliance on computer imagery that is abused (imo) a little too much in these modern times.

I use this to teach fantasy writing.  We start with the very beginning of the movie to set the scene, meet the characters, and establish the problem in the story.  I stop the movie and we start to journal the above story elements.  We add new characters and list events as the story unfolds.  We decide where the beginning becomes the middle and find where we think the end begins.  There are just too many teaching points to list!! I love this movie!

I was obsessed with this movie when. I was a kid. Watching it again as an adult I can see why. The sets and special effects are so advanced, and the story within a story concept is so creative. I had to ff through the 'horse' scene though - still makes me cry!

Unfortunately they do not make movies like this anymore.  It has all the bells and whistles of the struggle of good and evil, indifference and caring, and a child finding his way through a maze of grief.  I think a good age for this movie is about 7 years old.
loved watching it - story line was solid and easy to follow.  Music selections added alot to the movie. Kids really enjoyed it.

While some of the magic is gone, being a jaded adult, the message rings through clearer than ever.  I didn't know there was a book, and that the movie only adapts the first half of it.  I have ordered both the paperback and hardcover.  I found a handmade leather dust cover on Etsy that goes with the hardcover book so it looks very close to what it looks like in the movie.  There is a $200 edition of the book here on Amazon, but it's not that accurate.  I really wish someone would make an accurate replica of the book seen in the movie.  I would pay hundreds for it.

Anyway, the movie is a masterpiece on its own.  I was hesitant to watch it, as I didn't want to ruin the fond memories I had of it as a child.  But, surprisingly, it was great.  The message of the importance of hope and imagination were what I got from it for the first time, as I was only 12 years old or so the last time I watched it.  Einstein would be proud lol

Truly a classic movie.  It's a crying shame that the sequels are straight garbage.  I tried watching The Neverending Story II for free on Amazon Prime (heads up Amazon Prime members, if you can stomach that terrible movie), but could only get about halfway before me and the wife looked at each other and agreed that we couldn't keep watching.  It was that bad.  So, I'm excited to read the book.  I want to know the rest of Bastian's story!

Now, onto the Bluray itself.  It's not the best of picture quality, but not bad by any means.  Some scenes are worse than others.  There is a menu but no special features.  The options are: Play, Language, Scenes.  That's it.  It's been nearly 30 years since the theatrical release, so it would be nice to get a 30th Anniversary edition with commentaries and other extras.  I would totally double dip and not even feel bad about it.  That's how much I love this movie.
My six year old daughter loved it, she wanted to see it over and over. My three year old son also enjoyed it.
This is one of the best movies EVER! (And I'm not just saying that) I hope that if you have not seen it you will soon. This is a timeless movie that is made for everyone.

We introduced our kids to this movie and have enjoyed re-living the memories of watching it in our childhoods.  The story is timeless, the characters are so moving and our kids love it just as much as we do.  So glad it's been re-mastered on Blu-Ray!

I rented this because my wife (remarried) had never seen it.  It was a movie I and my children watched over and over when they were young.  Not fare for 3 and 4 year olds though.  8, 9 10 certainly.  (There's a big scary wolf in it).  My new wife loved it and it brought back wonderful memories.
I loved but obviously not for 8 year olds.  I tried to introduce to mine and she barely made it through 30 minutes.  Terrifieid her.  So might screen before you introduce to your little one!
This is the best movie ever. Me and the family enjoyed it from beginning to end. Almost wish we bought it.

This movie is enjoyable for children and adults.  The characters are so imaginative and diverse.  I like that this is a clean movie without much violence.  It has some positive messages in it as well, like not allowing sadness to overtake you.  It appeals to the kid in all of us.
This is the best movie ever made in the history of movies. The sequels are an insult to the original so don't waste your time on those. This is the most magical meaningful movie I have ever seen.
Best kids movie ever!! The special effects from the eighties, in this movie aren't even that bad, even with movie magic today. Lol .

The Blue Ray arrived pretty quickly. It would not, however, play in the Blue Ray player. Upon closer inspection, the art work looks a little...off. I think this is someone ripping disks off of their PC and selling them. Not worth it, buy one from a reputable company.
I grew up watching this movie and I love it. It is a classic, I have often wondered why someone doesn't remake it.

I loved this movie as a kid and really enjoyed watching my little ones watching it.  The picture on blu-ray looked so much better than what I remember seeing as a child.  Definitely recommend for family movie night!
My oldest daughter loved this movie when she was a kid, so I bought a cheap copy for my grandkids.  Although it is not tech savy as movies today, they really love it.
I grew up watching this movie and I never forgot it, it is really nice to own it, when I watch it I am still amazed!!! A true classic!!!
Reminds me of when I was little. One of my all time favorite movies from my childhood. A must buy

Our grandchildren enjoyed this tale as much as their Parents did, when we shared it with them so many years ago.

This tale of fantasy reminds us that we are all important players and links in our own never ending stories.

It has everything... humor, suspense, sadness, hope, redemption, you name it.  It's something you could show your kids every year, and they will get more out of it each time as they mature.  A favorite of mine as a kid, and now as an adult to show my children.

PS - In response to the small percentage of reviewers who did not like the movie... I would suggest they go back and try watching it again.  I think they have missed the whole point.  Again, it's a movie to grow on, with bigger ideals and meaning than most movies we have now become accustomed to watching.  It's a real roller coaster for younger kids, including fear and suspense.  Some may not be able to watch all of the scenes the first time through.  My youngest didn't - but this time she did.  It's a deep appreciation kind of movie.  A real art some may argue we've lost in all of our special affects.  This movie has heart!  The "scary scene" contains important information about the movie.  If you don't listen to the story as it unfolds, I can see why you might not like it.  It requires listening and processing.  I don't see that as a fault to the movie.  Without giving any spoilers away... if you did not cry or at least feel like crying during a certain very sad and intense scene in this movie, than you can not claimed to have watched it... because you never engaged with it.  It's not something to listen to in the background, it's an adventure to experience.

I'm glad so many of us have enjoyed this movie!

This movie is a CLASSIC and worth owning for futrure generations to see. Every child should see this movie. This is where imagination lives... In the written word and in a child's mind. You'll have your favorite characters and scenes for years to come and find yourself quoting all of the beautiful little literary things said. Just the mention of the movie sparks a smile and wonderful memories, even in your 30-somethings. Enjoy ;)

Nostalgia overload. Great picture. Watched it with my nephew, it was his first time viewing it, and we were both over-awed, wide eyed and slack jawed. My memories of the movie are VHS tinted, so this was great.
This has always been a favorite of mine, and yes, I am an adult, but who cares? I feel that this movie will bring out the kid in you, I recommend it for everyone at any age.

The Neverending Story was created many, many years ago. Despite this, and despite its antiquated animation, it remains a superb story for younger children.  My own began watching it right after it came out in 1984 and after three decades of movie watching and making they both still consider it a wonderful vision of an imagined world, of heroism and of connectedness.  I now have a two year old grandchild compellingly named Sebastian--'Bastian--for whose older sister this dvd purchase  is intended. This is a good movie to watch with the family. There are some scenes that are sad and/or scary at times, but other parts make up for it. I've seen parts of it on tv 20 years ago, but not until this evening did I watch it straight through. Wouldn't want to buy to own, but decided to rent it from Amazon Instant Video for a cheap movie night in. Not for nothing, technology can be good, but there is nothing like reading a good book and letting your imagination take flight. I don't have the book, but if I had a copy, I'll read it and imagine myself being ten years old again, stuck in a paperback book (Kindles weren't around in 1993). That's the joy of reading and was the point, to me anyway, in this movie. The scene with the bookshop owner hit it: Imaging your Captain Nemo in your submarine about to be attack by a squid, or being Robinson Crusoe on a deserted island. Allowing yourself to be part of the story.

The Neverending Story is a great film for the entire family. The Blu-ray sports picture and audio quality that is fairly average. The audio is a real shame because the music and score were excellent at the time of release. Also, no bonus supplements are provided. The Dutch BD import was likewise devoid of extras. A deluxe Blu-ray loaded with 3 hours of documentaries, commentaries and interviews would rate higher. It seems Warner Bros. did not take this film very seriously because not even a trailer is provided. This is a 4 star film in a 3 star release.

Video Resolution/Codec: 1080p/VC-1 | Aspect Ratio: 2.40:1
Audio Formats: English DTS-HD Master Audio 5.1, French Dolby Digital 2.0
Subtitles/Captions: English SDH, French, Spanish, Danish, Finnish, Norwegian, Portuguese, Swedish

This little sleeper of a film had modest theater success and even won a few awards in Europe. Noah Hathaway also was recognized with a nomination for Best at the Young Artist Awards and did win the Best Young Artist at the Academy of Science Fiction, Fantasy and Horror Films (USA), But it is as a rental and now as a purchase that it has found major success. Word of mouth between kids and parents has made this film huge. It has Wolfgang Peterson (Das Boot, Outbreak) for director & screenwriter and a very talented cast.

But the bottom line is it has the magic of great storytelling. It captures the imagination of young and old alike with fears, tears and finally cheers. This is a film that the whole family can enjoy together. For the very young it should be watched in one sitting as a few scenes are very sad or a bit scary; but all comes out fine in the end. If you aren't sure if your little one is ready for this film, first watch it yourself. You won't mind watching it twice. In fact, if your kids are like mine and now my granddaughter are you'll be watching it lot.

"The Neverending Story" is a film that centers around a boy named Bastian Bux who finds refuge in using his imagination and reading fiction books having to do with quests. He ends up reading a book set in the world Fantasia and unintentionally discovers that he plays a role in the outcome of this mystical world. Somehow, the destinies of Bastian Bux and the warrior Atreyu become intertwined. Atreyu gets help in his journey from a luck dragon named Falkor. The following actors/actresses are featured in "Neverending Story": Barrett Oliver, Noah Hathaway, Tami Stronach, Alan Oppenheimer, Thomas Hill, Deep Roy, Tilo Pruckner, Moses Gunn, Sydney Bromley, Patricia Hayes, and Gerald McRaney. "The Neverending Story" is a brilliant fantasy film for audiences of all ages.

First of all, the visual impacts were stunning; the music compelling. It was simply a beautifully crafted film. The characters, which we first meet in modern day, were sympathetic and relatable. Bastien, a mid-age youngster mourning his mother, takes refuge in a bookstore after being accosted by bullies. The shopkeeper, a man with a decided air of mystery, proffers a "dangerous" book; then conveniently turns his back allowing Bastien to make off with it. Holed up in a stuffy storage attic of his school with a thundersorm raging without, the magic begins to happen. He is suddenly immersed in a fantasy world that's being slowly dissolved by The Nothing. And the book is naming HIM as its saviour. "That's impossible!" he screams to a rain-pounded pane. But the book continues to write him into the story, following the footsteps of a hero his own age. He meets a variety of improbably appealing characters (the Luck Dragon was my favorite) and we move on through fearful obstacles and morality lessons toward a triumphal conclusion. My kids and I couldn't get enough of it!

Last night I decided to revisit one of my favorite films as a child: The Neverending Story. I was a little nervous that the movie wouldn't be as good as I remembered, but thankfully it was. Directed by Wolfgang Petersen, this 1984 film was met with mostly positive reviews upon its release. While the film grossed less in the U.S. than it cost to make, worldwide it pulled in more than $100 million and went on to become one of the best-selling home video releases ever.

The Neverending Story is based on the first half of the fantasy novel of the same name by Michael Ende. While I plan on reading the novel, I have yet to do so; therefore I can't compare the two. However, nearly 30 years later, the movie is still as visually stunning as I remember. Watching Atreyu traverse Fantasia in search of a way to save the Empress, was as spellbinding as I remembered. And the wonderfully majestic score, composed by Klaus Doldinger, brought back great memories, as well as the title song, which was composed by legendary disco producer Giorgio Moroder.

If you've never seen this movie, I highly recommend it. While some of the special effects look dated, the majority of them are still wonderful. More importantly, the acting is excellent and the story is charming. It's a wonderful film for those young and old, and it still ranks high on my list of all-time favorite films.

I just finished watching the blu ray version of this movie. I was actually surprised how much I enjoyed re-watching it. There was probably some nostalgia, but also scenes I had forgotten. It's been over 20 years. The visuals are really quite beautiful. Almost all of the special effects/ animatronics hold up as well as or better than modern CGI, which is surprising (or maybe not) and even better than most other movies from the era. Things like Falkor looking happy to have his ear scratched were amazing. The only weak part is a few superimposed images of Falkor flying, but they aren't bad. The story holds up as well since it is so literary grounded and those books and concepts aren't going anywhere.

My kids saw it for the first time and really enjoyed it. There were a few scary parts that I am pretty sure scared me a lot more as a child.

So the new blu ray transfer was very pretty, the subtitles were well done, but the only thing lacking was special features of which there are none. Not even a theatrical trailer. Still, the main presentation was great, so I highly recommend this version.

For those who remember renting Wolfgang Petersons The Neverending Story on VHS from their towns video store, it may occupy a special place on their shelfnot to mention in their heartand it should. It certainly occupies both of mine. For those who have never seen it, be prepared to be amazed.

The Neverending Story makes the ultimate example of getting caught up in an experience. Based on a children's fantasy novel by the German author Michael Ende, the plot concerns a boy reading a book and by doing so, becoming able to journey inside that book to wonder around in a real parallel universe. Fantasia, (or Fantastica in the book, probably a riff of the word fantasy) is being destroyed by humanity's lack of imaginationa nameless monster called The Nothing is literally eating space, leaving void in its wake. To get home, the boy must trek to the Ivory Tower to find an an ill princess and give her a new name, thus restoring the status quo. Two journeys are followed here: Bastion Balthazar Bux who reads The Neverending Story book, and Atreyu Greenskin the warrior, who has to find him and bring him from 1980s America into Fantasiaand maybe back again.

Filled with excellent special effects (considered groundbreaking for the day), lifelike puppet creatures similar to those of the Star Wars films, mayhem, drama, and adventurenot to mention a long list of fantastical creatures including a dragon, comical gnomes, and a giant turtle, this movie will entertain without repulsing. Violence is minimal and no profanity or gore.  Only serious elements like loss are examined, such as Atreyu s horse disappearing in a bog, along with threats from a frightening wolf near the movies climax.

On a personal level, no other film in my time, except perhaps Peter Jacksons fantasies like King Kong or The Lord of the Rings, has seized my attention the way this film (and later book) has done. I loved to read as a child, so the idea of being raptured as it were, into a book, of all things, totally fascinates me still today. The progression of events follows Campbells mythic structure to a tee. The only drawback to a film this short (at 90 minutes) remains obviously that the crew lacked the vision, ability, and tools in the 80s to see Michael Endes story through. If you have read the book, then you know two stories (one Atreyus, followed by Bastions) make up the entire work. Like the book Jurassic Park, and Tolkiens ring stories-turned films, much has been left to the viewers imagination. I still love the movie, and would rather have the story told a different way onscreen than have a parrot-back of what I read in the book. All three of these adaptations are absolutely fantastic, and we all would be so lucky to have any kind of attention paid to our fiction.

Kids of all ages will identify with the neglected and outcast Bastion, and parents will appreciate the simple moralalways keep childlike innocence about you and use (or lose) your imagination This movie is a classic. Despite grown-up themes and serious incidents of exploration, you will be mesmerized. The movie is rated PG for frightening images and thematic elements. The Region 1 DVD includes trailer and production notes.

The Never Ending Story, based on a German series of novels, is a timeless tale of an epic journey. For young and old alike, viewers of this film will experience the wonder of imagination, and feel inspired to think about the myths and legends that inform our own life journeys. Yes, the movie may seem outdated as far a special effects go, but that should not really matter to fans of science fiction or fantasy who enjoy good storytelling. All of the stages of a hero's journey are beautifully told in this film, mirroring Joseph Campbell's theory that myths are created by us to inform us of our destiny and place in the cosmos. This tale is timeless, and perfectly captures the epic journey of rising above your own doubts an fears to embrace your destiny. The special effects for this time won this film numerous accolades in the 1980's. I will caution you all NOT to watch the sequels of this film, as they veer far from the original vision of the books and ruin the story. Stick to this film, and enjoy the magic of a good story.

I remember watching this as a child and it really was a never-ending story - an epic of great proportions.  In fact, I was probably a lot like Bastian, really getting into the story and living it, and it felt like it went on for ages as you traveled with the characters.  As an adult, my first reaction was "wow, is the movie over already?"  It just went so much faster and while it still had charm, I couldn't believe the different perspective I had.

Bastian lives with his father after the death of his mother.  A small boy and quiet by nature, he is often the target of bullies.  It is on one day, when he is running from said bullies, that he stumbles into a store where an old man shows him a mysterious book called The Neverending Story.  Knowing he has to read it, Bastian slips out of the shop with the book (but assures the owner in a note he'll bring it back) and takes it to school.  There in the attic, he starts to read the book and becomes a part of a world called Fantasia, where the nothingness is taking over and the empress is dying and only a young boy named Atreyu can help save it.  But to do so he must go on a dangerous journey, where his wit and skills will be tested.

Characters:
Barret Oliver: Bastian Bux
Noah Hathaway: Atreyu
Tami Stronach: The Empress
Alan Oppenheimer: Falkor, Gmork, Rock Biter and the Narrator
Moses Gunn: Cairon
Sydney Bromley: Engywook

I don't really remember caring either way about Bastian as a child.  As an adult I find him a tad annoying, but at least his imagination and zest for reading is charming.  And he does seem like a realistic little boy.  Oliver did a good job filling the role.  Hathaway as Atreyu was quite good too.  He had to do a lot of different things in the movie and he pulled them off admirably.  He had the right amount of spunk that brave Atreyu needed as well.  The only other character that got a ton of screen time was Falkor and since he was a dragon, his voice was appropriately deep and commanding (as done by Oppenheimer).  He's a likable dragon though, with a certain jovialness to him that's appealing.  The other characters are all neat, but they play small roles and in my opinion, not used to the best of their abilities.  But they do paint the picture for what Fantasia is like.

This is an adventure movie.  It's based off of a book (which I have not yet read but will eventually) and I can't really say how well it follows the book.  I'm assuming well since it seems like the author had a big hand in how the movie was made.  As said before though, while this movie went slowly as a child, it moves very very fast as an adult.  Almost rushed.  So as much as I would like to give it the highest rating, there are some flaws there that nostalgia just can't fix for me.  This is a kids movie, and it's appropriate for kids, however, there are some very hard themes that are expressed in it.  Loss, violence, sorrow; just to name a few.

For being made in the eighties, this movie had some decent special effects.  The dragon Falkor alone was well done and lifelike, and even a bit scary for a young child.  Likewise the other characters had neat costumes.  The only thing I really found hokey would be the castle in the end, it was just a little out there.  But really, well done.  And then there's the music.  Epic music, I loved all of it.  Mainly because it brought back memories but there's just something so catchy about it all, and it was written specifically for the movie so it's very fitting as well.

This movie brings back a lot of memories, and while it's not quite what I remembered it's still very good.  It's one of those movies that all ages will like too so it's a good one for family night.  Enjoy this jewel!

I usually never spend my time writing reviews of movies or products. But in this case I felt I had to vent about this utter disappointment that Warner Home Video has produced. This review is not about the movie itself so much as the Blu-ray and it's shortcomings. Especially when compared to the DVD which says a lot because there was only ever 1 DVD release of this fantastic film and it was even among the first generation of DVDs produced, and it STILL whoops the Blu-ray's ass no contest.

This release is a horrible injustice to anyone who is a fan of this movie and has been eagerly been anticipating its "upgraded" Blu-ray version. I loved this movie as a kid and I still love it as an adult. Plot & story aside, the movie is quite literally a cinematic work of art. A true visual & aural masterpiece of the fabled 80s era of movies that a lot of us grew up with. To this day there are very few true fantasy films out there, and this one has always been among the classic greats of my generation.

If ever a movie deserved a top quality re-transfer & release, it is this one. Not many people have never heard of The NeverEnding Story. The DVD release was actually pretty damn good. and I could understand why Warner Bros. stepped back and decided it didn't need a 2nd release on DVD. But then in 2006 Blu-ray made its debut, and many of us avid movie collectors became very excited about the prospect of seeing the movies that we grew up with look so good in pristine 1080p.

At first I was a bit jaded about the whole thing, because I had already spent so much money over the years amassing my vast DVD collection. And now here comes big bad Blu-ray to try to make me start all over again and make my DVDs look inferior by comparison. But when the prices came down I decided to give Blu-ray a chance, and am so happy I did because it is (usually) a massive step up from DVD. But not this one... : ( Nope, this disc is a waste of both money and of plastic.

I have seen what this format is truly capable of. Even on older movies, if true care is put into them, the Blu-ray release can make a movie look like it was shot yesterday with a digital film camera. They could have extended that level of care to this epic masterpiece that Wolfgang Peterson created. But instead they just half-assed its transfer & "clean-up" and got it out on store shelves just as fast as they could to make a quick buck off of unsuspecting hopefuls like myself. Truly intolerable.

First of all, they made NO effort at ALL to clean up the picture quality. There is grain grain grain. Grain everywhere throughout the film. Even the glorious opening credits look like trash. Had they truly given a damn, they could have taken the original negative and ran it through todays much more advanced & thorough telecine filters & digital encoders. They could have made the picture absolutely flawless. And they definitely SHOULD have. But they didn't do anything of the sort.

I mean they did a pretty good job cleaning up this film for DVD compared to the VHS release for what it was. That was back in the late 90s. We've come a long way since then and they could have taken the digital restoration efforts to a whole new level. Eliminated every spec of grain and made this film look brand spankin' new. Sure, the picture is sharper than the DVD only because it's now presented in 1080p. But that really just means more defined grain in this case.

Next up is color. Whatever lazy idiot was put in charge of this specific title, that person should really look into another line of work. Because they clearly attempted some form of crappy color correction here by vastly & obviously changing whole entire palettes throughout the film. It's especially apparent in the first few chapters of the Blu-ray  right after Bastian starts reading the book. Especially the one where the Ivory Tower is revealed for the first time. It's almost entirely ORANGE!! God it looks absolutely hideous! The once vibrant & picturesque colors are now all washed out and dull, and completely drowned out but the orange hue they implemented.

They messed with the hues & saturation levels all over the film, but it's the worst here. And this was one of the coolest parts of the movie. The introduction to Fantasia and to the story's hero and to the quest he must undertake. All garbage now. On top of all that, they lowered the brightness considerably everywhere. But especially here. Now it's so dark that you can barely see what the heck is going on. When Atreyu leaves on his horse Artax, you can't even see it because it's so dark!

I get what these sloppy fools were trying achieve here. Something to do with "The sun was setting, so we thought it would be better if we stayed more consistent with that by flooding the scenes with orange sunlight. And then by the time Atreyu takes off, it would be already nearly dark, so let's try to fix that now, shall we?" Idiots. Amateurs. All they really did was drag the picture quality through the digital mud. It's freakin' FANTASIA for God's sake! Time & true-to-life color have no meaning here!

If you play the DVD and the Blu-ray together and make the visual comparison, you will quite clearly see the vast differences I have pointed out. The DVD is brighter, more vivid, and most importantly truer to the original release. The film-makers & production designers made their choices and they were good ones. Who are these jokers to mess with that? It looked way WAY better the way it was originally.

Look. Bottom line here, people, is that this is an all around failure of a Blu-ray transfer. It does NOT enhance the experience one bit. Visually I mean. Sure it's 1080p now. But what good is that if it still looks like crap? They actually managed to make it WORSE than it was before, on the most modern medium. It's like they just transfered the VHS to a Blu-ray disc. In fact the only improvement they DID make was the sound is now the lossless DTS 5.1 mix. So if you're blind, this is a sensible upgrade to buy.

I hope & pray that Warner Home Video does the right thing in time and sees these flaws for what they are and decides to step up to the plate and give this movie a REAL Blu-ray release where there is NO grain anymore, the colors are preserved & enhanced, the brightness levels are left as they were and it just all around looks incredible when compared to the DVD and this terrible first Blu-ray release. But considering it only ever got 1 DVD release, it's a slim chance that'll happen. I wanna cry.

If I was Wolfgang Peterson, I would take more pride in my movies and ensure they when they get released to the world on a new medium, that they're getting the attention to detail that they need to have. If I wanted to show this movie to my kids or to someone who has never seen it before, I would pull out the DVD and watch it in 720p, rather than have their 1st experience with this timeless classic be this trashy Blu-ray.

DO NOT BUY THIS STEAMING PILE OF CRAP BLU-RAY. I promise you you will be summarily & thoroughly let down with what you witness. Case closed.

This video was pretty entertaining. I was a little hesitant to watch it, seeing as it was made in 1984, but the storyline is very interesting and kept me unaware of what would happen next. It was equal parts magical, whismical, and fantastical. The 1980's special effects were a little strange (compared to how realistic special effects and cgi makes everything look now). Overall, fun. The little boy who played Atreyu was so cute - who knew he would grow into a man with tattoos all over both arms. The child empress played her part well. I think the rock biter was probably one of my favorite characters. I enjoyed watching him eat rocks.

In the fantasy/SF- crowded year of 1984, we also got this, "The Neverending Story."
Being a lifelong SF/fantasy film fan, this one was certainly a part of my childhood, although I quickly relegated it to second or third tier interest, seeing it only once in a great while. After well over a decade of not seeing it, I watched it again while comparing its two soundtracks. The New -Wave/-Age-ish title ballad is one of the better songs of the genre, and the actual score has its moments. Oddly, I found myself often comparing this to the same year's "Supergirl."

One scene sums up my attitude to this movie, then or now, which prevented me from taking it as seriously as other fantasy/SF flicks. When he reads about the death of Artax (Atreju's trusty horse), it's scored by a standard, unengaging death march, and the overacting is rife on both boys' faces. While I am saddened by the death of any animal (and most people), the scene was either flat or eye-rolling for me. If I didn't suspect it already, by then I *knew* this was a movie I wouldn't be able to take very seriously. Oh, it picked up and improved and had some nice scenes and plot points and characterizations thereafter, but for all intents and purposes it had already reduced itself to a standard-issue cut-and-dry fantasy movie, albeit with some really sweet visuals and some decent bits of score.

While there's something to be said for the theme of preserving and encouraging imagination, it just seems so lame that 'Bastian wastes almost the entire movie escaping reality and responsibility (in his school's storage room, no less); he ironically refuses to use/release his imagination until the very last second; and then solves his bully problem by scaring them into dumpsters. Jeez, he has no future at this rate.

Yes, this movie is pure cheese: it's not as stinky as limburger, it's not sharp as cheddar, it's more like standard American cheese, mass-produced and shrink-wrapped for your average ordinary sandwich. It's not great, but it's healthy and good enough to revisit once in a while.

Purchased this again years after seeing it the first time when our kids were little. thought i'd have to borrow someone's grandchildren to watch it again but two of our twenty-something's stopped to watch for a minute and before long they were snuggled under blankets on the couch and floor to experience "The Story" all over again like old times. one of those pure imagination stories that anyone can get lost in. just enough humor, scary stuff, fantasy, special effects and life lessons to appeal to just about anyone with a pulse.

SPOILERS FOLLOW

"The Neverending Story" is a 1984 fantasy film from director Wolfgang Petersen.  Loosely adapted from Michael Ende's book of the same name(in its English translation from the original German), it stars Barret Oliver and Noah Hathaway.

The movie tells the story of Bastian Bux(Oliver) and his compelling imaginative and psychological connection to the mythical land of Fantasia.  After essentially stealing the title tome from a grumpy and strange bookstore proprietor, Bastian reads it alone in a school attic as his fertile mind devours the odd story.  Arguably no other film makes such an effective, all-encompassing statement regarding the pyschological and emotional connection between readers and their books.  Noah Hathaway delivers a richly nuanced performance as the child warrior Atreyu, called on to save Fantasia from the murderous grasp of The Nothing.  The concept and function of The Nothing as detailed in the movie is extremely imaginative, and occasionally potentially very frightening for young children.

Produced in an era before widespread computer-generated effects in movies, the wild landscapes of Fantasia are still extremely impressive.  Atreyu's flight through the sky with the kind luckdragon Falkor and slog through the dreary Swamps of Sadness are visual highpoints.  However, the movie is rated a stern PG for mature and violent content.  The tone makes for an overall classic, but also a film that should be screened by parents or guardians before very young children see it.

"The Neverending Story"  is an enduring classic fantasy film.
